article.description: After West Virginia coach Bob Huggins dropped to his knees and clutched his chest in a scary moment before halftime, Jevon Carter finished with 24 points to lead No. 12 WVU to a win over Texas.

article.headline: After Huggins' scary moment, No. 12 WVU beats Texas 77-62

images.name: Allen says 'get on my poster'
images.caption: Jarrett Allen throws down potential dunk of the year over West Virginia's Sagaba Konate.

article.linkText: After Huggins' scary moment, No. 12 WVU beats Texas 77-62
article.story:
MORGANTOWN, W.Va. -- Bob Huggins fell to his knees and clutched his chest during a scary moment just before halftime.

West Virginia players picked up their coach, got him to the bench and made his job easier by maintaining a comfortable lead the rest of the way Monday night.

Jevon Carter had 24 points and Lamont West had a career-high 23, helping the 12th-ranked Mountaineers roll to a 77-62 win over Texas following Huggins' frightening fall.

Huggins went down on the court during a timeout just before the half, and his players quickly came to his aid. Huggins stood, briefly massaged his chest and returned to the sideline.

Huggins said his defibrillator went off, but he returned to coach in the second half and finished the game.

"It comes out of nowhere," Huggins said. "Well, I guess I got a little lightheaded, which I do when I stand up too fast sometimes. A lot of that's old age, and a lot of it is some of the medication I take.

"Then, I mean honestly, the defibrillator went off," Huggins added. "But, that's second time it's been going off. It goes off and what it is, it just shocks your heart back into rhythm."

The 63-year-old Huggins had a heart attack at the Pittsburgh airport in 2002 when he was the coach at Cincinnati. He was back in his office two weeks later.

Texas coach Shaka Smart later exchanged well wishes with Huggins.

Once it was apparent their coach was OK, the Mountaineers continued rolling over the Longhorns. West made 6 of 8 tries from 3-point range, helping WVU (22-6, 10-5 Big 12) shake off a slow start.

"When I'm on the court, I always feel like I'm going to hit a shot," West said, "but today was just a different feeling."

Carter also grabbed 10 rebounds for his third double-double of the season, and Elijah Macon had 10 points.

Texas started the game on a 12-2 run but trailed 46-32 at halftime. Jarrett Allen led the Longhorns (10-18, 4-11) with 17 points.

"We really wanted to come out and be the more aggressive team to start the game," Smart said. "I thought our guys did a good job of that."

BIG PICTURE

Texas has lost four straight and five of six. The Longhorns have upcoming games against No. 3 Kansas and No. 9 Baylor, so a strong finish does not look likely.

West Virginia clinched a bye in the Big 12 Tournament with its fourth win in five games. WVU had two players score 20-plus points for the first time this season.

NO PLACE LIKE HOME

Texas has yet to win a road game this season. The Longhorns are on a 15-game losing streak away from home dating to the Big 12 Tournament last season. Texas has one remaining road game at Texas Tech, on March 1.

AHMAD OUT

West Virginia's Esa Ahmad sat out due to back spasms and is day-to-day. Ahmad averages 11.7 points and 4.1 rebounds per game.

UP NEXT

Texas hosts No. 3 Kansas on Saturday.

West Virginia plays at TCU on Saturday.

videos.headline: Defensive effort has Texas out to fast start
videos.description: Kerwin Roach Jr. gets a huge block to lead to an easy transition layup for Eric Davis Jr.

videos.headline: Allen rocks the rim with huge two handed slam
videos.description: Jarrett Allen throws down a huge dunk after picking up an offensive rebound.

videos.headline: West picks up 4-point play
videos.description: Lamont West knocks down the 3-point jumper through the foul

videos.headline: West Virginia using defense to grab momentum
videos.description: West Virginia picks up two huge blocks, one of which leads to a Jevon Carter 3.

videos.headline: Furious Smart picks up tech after non-call
videos.description: Shaka Smart picks up a technical foul after he was upset with a non-call on the previous play.

videos.headline: Roach finishes amazing and-1 layup
videos.description: Kerwin Roach Jr. makes an amazing reverse layup through a foul.

videos.headline: Scary scene as Huggins collapses on court
videos.description: West Virginia coach Bob Huggins collapses on the court during a timeout. He would get to his feet and return in the second half.

videos.headline: Questionable foul has West Virginia baffled
videos.description: West Virginia picks up a foul on a play that appears to have Texas teammates colliding with each other.

videos.headline: Macon alley-oop dunk seals it down the stretch for West Virginia
videos.description: Elijah Macon throws down huge alley oop dunk.

videos.headline: Huggins talks about WVU's 77-62 win over Texas
videos.description: West Virginia head coach Bob Huggins talks about his team's 77-62 win over Texas.

videos.headline: Huggins blames defibrillator for fall
videos.description: West Virginia coach Bob Huggins explains what caused him to fall on the court during the first half against Texas, saying, "It comes out of nowhere."

videos.headline: West lifts West Virginia past Texas
videos.description: Lamont West's career-high 23 points pushes No. 12 West Virginia to a 77-62 victory over Texas.

videos.headline: Texas' Allen throws down dunk of the year candidate in loss
videos.description: Texas forward Jarrett Allen gets the ball in the paint and puts West Virginia's Sagaba Konate on a poster with a vicious one-handed jam.

tracking.trackingName: COM_NCB Highlight (Texas' Allen throws down dunk of the year candidate in loss) 2017/02/20 ENHL
